1.text: “Do you know when mountain goats give birth? Have you watched the doe bear her fawn?

2.text: Can you count the months they are pregnant? Do you know the time they give birth?

3.text: They crouch down and bring forth their young; they deliver their newborn.

4.text: Their young ones thrive and grow up in the open field; they leave and do not return.

5.text: Who set the wild donkey free? Who released the swift donkey from the harness?

6.text: I made the wilderness his home and the salt flats his dwelling.

7.text: He scorns the tumult of the city and never hears the shouts of a driver.

8.text: He roams the mountains for pasture, searching for any green thing.

9.text: Will the wild ox consent to serve you? Will he stay by your manger at night?

10.text: Can you hold him to the furrow with a harness? Will he plow the valleys behind you?

11.text: Can you rely on his great strength? Will you leave your hard work to him?

12.text: Can you trust him to bring in your grain and gather it to your threshing floor?

13.text: The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, but cannot match the pinions and feathers of the stork.

14.text: For she leaves her eggs on the ground and lets them warm in the sand.

15.text: She forgets that a foot may crush them, or a wild animal may trample them.

16.text: She treats her young harshly, as if not her own, with no concern that her labor was in vain.

17.text: For God has deprived her of wisdom; He has not endowed her with understanding.

18.text: Yet when she proudly spreads her wings, she laughs at the horse and its rider.

19.text: Do you give strength to the horse or adorn his neck with a mane?

20.text: Do you make him leap like a locust, striking terror with his proud snorting?

21.text: He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength; he charges into battle.

22.text: He laughs at fear, frightened of nothing; he does not turn back from the sword.

23.text: A quiver rattles at his side, along with a flashing spear and lance.

24.text: Trembling with excitement, he devours the distance; he cannot stand still when the ram’s horn sounds.

25.text: At the blast of the horn, he snorts with fervor. He catches the scent of battle from afar, the shouts of captains and the cry of war.

26.text: Does the hawk take flight by your understanding and spread his wings toward the south?

27.text: Does the eagle soar at your command and make his nest on high?

28.text: He dwells on a cliff and lodges there; his stronghold is on a rocky crag.

29.text: From there he spies out food; his eyes see it from afar.

30.text: His young ones feast on blood; and where the slain are, there he is.”
